title: Nosebleed
description: A nosebleed occurs when blood vessels inside the nose break, causing blood to flow out. It can be triggered by factors such as dry air, allergies, injury, or irritation.

sections.heading: Symptoms of a Nosebleed
sections.content: Blood flowing from one or both nostrils, which may be bright red or darker depending on the source. There may be a feeling of fullness or pressure in the nose and dryness or irritation before bleeding starts.

sections.heading: Steps for Basic Nosebleed Care
sections.content:
1) Stay calm to avoid raising blood pressure.
2) Sit up straight and lean forward slightly to prevent blood from flowing down the throat. Do NOT lie down.
3) Pinch your nostrils together using your thumb and index finger, breathe through your mouth, and maintain pressure for 5â€“10 minutes without peeking.
4) Apply a cold compress to the back of the neck or bridge of the nose to constrict blood vessels.
5) After bleeding stops, avoid blowing your nose, keep it moist with saline spray or petroleum jelly, and avoid picking or scratching inside the nostrils.

sections.heading: Precautions to Prevent Nosebleeds
sections.content:
Use a humidifier in dry environments to maintain moisture.
Avoid picking or forceful blowing of the nose.
Use saline sprays to keep nasal passages moist.
Wear protective gear during activities that risk nose injury.
Manage allergies with appropriate medications to reduce nasal irritation.

sections.heading: When to Seek Emergency Care
sections.content:
If bleeding lasts more than 20 minutes despite care.
If bleeding follows a head injury.
If the person has trouble breathing or swallowing blood.
If frequent nosebleeds occur or blood clotting disorders are present.
If bleeding happens after taking blood thinners like aspirin or warfarin.

sections.heading: Emergency Medicine for Nosebleeds
sections.content:
Cauterization may be performed by a doctor to seal bleeding vessels.
Nasal packing with gauze or sponges might be needed for severe bleeding.
Topical vasoconstrictors may be applied to narrow blood vessels and stop bleeding.

sections.heading: What Not to Do
sections.content:
Do NOT tilt your head back as it can cause blood to flow into the throat, risking choking.
Do NOT insert tissues or cotton into the nose.
Do NOT lie down, which may increase nasal blood pressure.
